esp:page.esp:name: Emacs for ATF
esp:page.esp:title: Working with ATF in Emacs using atf-mode

body.p: An Emacs major mode is available which makes editing ATF files a bit easier and gives access to the template generator and checker.
If you name your files using the extension .atf, Emacs will automatically switch into ATF mode when you create a new file or load an existing one.
If you name your files using another extension, for example .txt, you can set the mode explicitly by typing Esc-x (escape then x) and then entering atf-mode at the prompt.
You can now use the ATF menu to read the ATF mode help, which will in turn tell you how to use the other menu items effectively.

li.p: Use menu File Visit new file to open a new file
If your new file does not have a .atf extension, enter ATF mode manually
Enter a template specification in your new file; you can access the template help from the ATF menu
When you have completed your template, select menu Create Template
Review the block structure you have created; if is incorrect, use the undo function to remove the block structure, edit the template specification and recreate the template
When you are satisfied with your template, delete the template specification

body.p: Although you can use the menu, there are two particularly useful keystrokes for working with the checker:

dl.dd: This is control-c then control-c again. This runs the checker and displays the results in another window.

This is control-c then control-n. This moves the cursor to the next erroneous line in your ATF file (it is often easier to use this key than C-x-`, which is the mainstream key-binding for the next-error command.

body.esp:h: Using Tramp to Edit Files on a Server
body.p: Emacs includes a package named tramp which can be used to edit files on a remote machine. This means that if you work on a project which is hosted on oracc.museum.upenn.edu you can keep the files there and edit them using Emacs. When you save the file it is saved back to the server.

body.esp:sh: Checker fails on Windows with strange '&P123456' results
body.p: Check the XML-RPC Customization option 'Xml Rpc Allow Unicode String': if it is not set to 'nil', then set it to 'nil' and try again.
(To find this option, try Options -> Customize Emacs -> Settings Matching Regexp and type xml-rpc-* at the prompt.)
body.esp:sh: Using a Remote Access Program, e.g., HummingBird
body.p: If you are having difficulty connecting via a graphical user interface to SSH and friends, check that all of the following are correct:

li.p: User ID = your project's abbreviation, in lowercase letters
Password = the correct password for your project
Starting Directory = the path /home/ followed by your project's abbreviation, in lowercase letters.

body.p: The Emacs ATF package includes an input method which is based on the Emacs MULE TeX input method but adds some characters which are useful for cuneiform transliterations. If the ATF mode package is installed correctly this input method is available under the name 'Cuneiform'.
To use this input method:

li.p: Use control-backslash (\) to switch the Cuneiform input method on and off; when the method is enabled you will see a backslash at the left end of the status line
